issues.title: make it easy to swap between native and emscripten obfuscators
issues.body:
Right now, uTransformers only exposes emscripten-ified obfuscators. It would be very nice to be able to easily add native implementations, e.g. this rabbit cipher:
https://code.google.com/p/crypto-js/

We could start by porting over the crappy Caesar cipher from turn-relay:
https://github.com/uProxy/turn-relay/blob/master/src/transformers/caesar.ts

issue_comments.body: We can. I didn't do that only because this repo isn't a JS repo like many of our others...but I think it would be totally fine. Done.

So, this is great. I love how we can have a single page with all our tests. Overall, it seems to strike a reasonable balance between keeping the "test harness" code small without making it too onerous to add additional ciphers in future, if we ever do that.

A big improvement. Just a couple of comments I would consider adding then please merge.

:+1:

Hey Kevin,

Overall, great. I patched this in, ran it locally and just have a couple of easily-fixed notes:
- Am I right to say that the "final output" goes into `build/`? I think the README should mention that.
- I think the top-level README should also mention that you need to run `grunt build` having _first_ compiled under vagrant. 
- Maybe `grunt clean` should clean out the files generated with `vagrant up`?
- I tried to open `vagrant/uTransformers/html/benchmark.html` and while the rabbit tests worked, the FTE tests fail due to `dist/regex2dfa.js` missing.
- In `vagrant/README.md`, I think we need to update the path to `benchmark.html` (`vagrant/uTransformers/html/benchmark.html`).

I think it will be pretty hard to make uTransformers handle block splitting and combining...but, yes, this is something we need to be on top of. I filed another issue:
https://github.com/uProxy/turn-relay/issues/28

https://github.com/uProxy/uTransformers/issues/32

issues.title: Improve uTransformers in-browser benchmarks
issues.body:
The current in-browser benchmarks focus on cases that are now highly-optimized in libfte, and may report optimistic performance numbers.

We should update the in-browser performance tests such that we can (1) compare fte directly to rabbit and (2) get throughput numbers for the uProxy use cases.

issue_comments.body: LGTM

This is our baseline for emscripten, using the default llvm-3.3 provided by Ubuntu.

### Firefox

![firefox llvm-3 3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2654449/3261684/7957e538-f25c-11e3-8f98-4c1f2c739716.png)

### Chrome

![chrom llvm-3 3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2654449/3261685/80facef4-f25c-11e3-98af-dd31ac2b3e59.png)

Then, this is the performance using the emscripten-fastcomp [1] compiler. (The only changes are in commit 7f1001be2fb20793517e8cbba008823db3c4fd11.)

### Firefox

![firefox fastcomp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2654449/3261704/c5712718-f25c-11e3-8971-69bb364dea9d.png)

### Chrome

![chrome fastcomp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2654449/3261702/c03c6e88-f25c-11e3-8d0b-c99a801eff54.png)

### References

[1] https://github.com/kripken/emscripten/wiki/LLVM-Backend
Got the thumbs up from Trevor over email.

I have an overview of how to build uTransformers at [1]. Unfortunately, the commands to execute are more complex than `./configure && make ...`, hence it's abstracted as a vagrant build. In [1] I try to justify the relatively complex build process.

I also tried to breakdown the build into modular components [2]. For example, the build process for uTransformers is in [3], but requires that all dependencies are installed. The hurdles are that (1) uTransformers dependencies are complex to build under emscripten and (2) for performance reasons, we must compile emscripten from source.

Ideally, libfte would be an npm module in it's own right (and rabbit too) then we could make uTransformers into a pure javascript/typescript project.

### References

[1] https://github.com/uProxy/uTransformers/tree/master/vagrant
[2] https://github.com/uProxy/uTransformers/blob/master/vagrant/bootstrap.sh
[3] https://github.com/uProxy/uTransformers/blob/master/vagrant/build_utransformers.sh

**Summary of issue:** To increase runtime performance, we pre-compute a lookup table in `uTransformers.fte.configure`. The size of this table for the plaintext language is roughly (number of states in the dfa) x (`plaintext_max_len`) x (a small constant) bytes. (And replacing `ciphertext_max_len` similarly for the ciphertext language.) So, by changing the regex, this table size can decrease/increase, depending upon the number of states in the minimal DFA. This table is the culprit behind the `Cannot enlarge memory arrays` error.

Fortunately, we can ameliorate this issue on three fronts:
- There will soon be a new release of libfte. This release of libfte will treat `.*` and `.+` as special cases. Lookup tables will not be required, and we'll have even faster runtime performance. This means the input plaintext language will require nearly-zero memory for `.*` and `.+`.
- We'll enable `ALLOW_MEMORY_GROWTH` in uTransformers, assuming it doesn't negatively impact performance.
- Then, as Shanjian says, we'll probably never want `ciphertext_max_len` to exceed ~1500.

With the three changes above, I expect we shouldn't encounter memory issues again, unless we start exploring super-complex regexes with a large number of DFA states.

This is an odd problem, because it appears that rabbit is working well in `uTransformers.rabbit`. However, when I try to reproduce the code in simple cases, I'm unable to call `RabbitCryptor::keysetup`, without causing a segfault.

Details:
- The segfault happens at line [1].
- If I provide a solution to [1], we get a segfault at [2].
- If I provide a solution to [2], then double-free errors start to appear.

**My attempted solution:** Shouldn't `k0 = U8TO32_LITTLE(key_int[0]);` at [1] be `k0 = U8TO32_LITTLE(key + 0);`? (And a similar change to the following three lines.)

### References

[1] https://github.com/uProxy/uTransformers/blob/74bb03ef043c40684b167667e62fe7377db01692/src/transformers/rabbit.cc#L97
[2] https://github.com/uProxy/uTransformers/blob/74bb03ef043c40684b167667e62fe7377db01692/src/transformers/rabbit.cc#L153

In future, we should structure uTransformers such that it's easy to swap between native implementations and other implementations (e.g. emscripten compiled.)

Would be very interesting to compare the performance of the native implementation to our emscripten-compiled version.

Here is a screenshot from the in-browser tests, as of ce6dd32.

![screen shot 2014-07-15 at 10 18 29 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2654449/3588618/7c7e5f3c-0c45-11e4-9d54-97508a62f964.png)

review_comments.body:
At the moment, this code is assumed to run in a 32-bit linux VM. There are a whole host of serious problems if this is run on OSX, or any 64-bit platform.

I currently have this documented a bit in `vagrant/README.md`. However, it might be useful to explain this in greater details.

issue_comments.body:
Shouldn't that be block size? uTransformer should handle block split and
combine.

We will need Kevin's help here. He will be back on Thursday.

shanjian

On Tue, Jul 8, 2014 at 5:05 PM, trevj notifications@github.com wrote:

> I'm using uTransformers as part of a TURN server. Chrome uses the TURN
> server to establish a peer-to-peer connection. Some of the packets used to
> negotiate the connection are much larger than I've being performing tests
> with until now: ~900 bytes. When I try to raise the input length to 1024 I
> start running into the following error when I instantiate the transformer:
> 
> Cannot enlarge memory arrays. Either (1) compile with -s TOTAL_MEMORY=X
> with X higher than the current value 16777216, (2) compile with
> ALLOW_MEMORY_GROWTH which adjusts the size at runtime but prevents some
> optimizations, or (3) set Module.TOTAL_MEMORY before the program runs.
> 
> But, it's not just the input length. For example, if I set both input and
> output regexes to '^.+$' then the transformer works fine. So, I don't
> really understand the relationship between the regexes and input and output
> lengths. FWIW, here's a config that fails:
> 
> {
>   'plaintext_dfa': regex2dfa('^.+$'),
>   'plaintext_max_len': 1024,
>   'ciphertext_dfa': regex2dfa('^[a-zA-Z0-9]+$'),
>   'ciphertext_max_len': 4096}
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/uProxy/uTransformers/issues/25.

Right, split and merge will be hard. FTE transformer should transform the
udp packet, unlike general block cipher.  I withdrew my previous comment.

UDP in ipv4 has 576 as the _minimum maximum reassembly buffer size. Common
practice is to control the payload size to be within 512.  To relatively
safe passing UDP over network, taking MTU as 1500, max size of udp is 1472.
I believe most UDP protocol should control its msg within that range. FTE
transformer just need to support up to that size?_

_shanjian_

On Wed, Jul 9, 2014 at 9:03 AM, trevj notifications@github.com wrote:

> I think it will be pretty hard to make uTransformers handle block
> splitting and combining...but, yes, this is something we need to be on top

Thanks for reporting this. I will take a look tomorrow.

shanjian
